answers: iPhone [accept more specific versions of an iPhone; prompt on smart phone]
Sean Baker (The first film is Tangerine.)
South Korea [or Republic of Korea, or ROK, or Daehan Minguk; prompt on Korea] (The directors of Night Fishing are Park Chan-kyong and Park Chan-wook; the director of Burning is Lee Chang-dong.)
parts: Identify these devices that Soderbergh also used to film Unsane. The XR edition of these devices include an "enhanced bokeh ("BO-keh") effect" in the camera app.

This director used an iPhone to shoot a 2015 film that opens with a trans sex worker named Sin-Dee being released from prison. Moonee lives in a purple motel called the "Magic Castle" in this director's film The Florida Project.

Two directors from this country used an iPhone 4 to collaboratively shoot the 2011 short film Night Fishing. A 2018 film from this country features a character who goes around burning rural greenhouses.

answers: South Africa [or Republic of South Africa; or RSA; or iRiphabhuliki yase Ningizimu Afrika; or iRiphabliki yom Zantsi Afrika; or Republiek van Suid-Afrika; or similar names from other languages]
wine industry [or vineyards or viticulture or equivalents; prompt on alcohol industry; prompt on grapes or Vitis]
Broad-Based Black Economic Empowerment [or B-BEE]
parts: Name this country whose 1998 Correctional Services Act let it contract Wackenhut Security to run the Louis Trichardt and Mangaung private prisons. Prisoners got rights in this country's 1993 Interim Constitution.
Right-wing media has played up "farm attacks" on South African landowners like Stefan Smit, who held an estate in this industry near Stellenbosch. Huguenots grew Sémillon varietals for this industry.
South Africa's KWV wine brand sold 25% of its shares to a consortium for this affirmative action policy that awards incentives to compliant businesses with Black ownership.

answers: Sarah Vowell [or Sarah Jane Vowell]
presidential libraries [accept presidential centers; accept presidential museums; accept specific presidential libraries; prompt on libraries or museums] (The robot is an animatronic LBJ.)
Little Rock, Arkansas [accept LR]
parts: Name this author who explored the legacy of colonial Massachusetts in The Wordy Shipmates.

Sarah Vowell's The Partly Cloudy Patriot describes touring these places, including one with a robot that tells jokes about a doctor's appointment. Tod Williams Billie Tsien ("tsee-EN") Architects designed one of these places that NARA plans to make 95% digital.

This city contains Bill Clinton's presidential library as well as Heifer International's headquarters and the Mosaic Templars Cultural Center. The Clinton Foundation also maintains an office in this capital of Arkansas.

answers: neem tree [or nimtree; or Indian lilac; or Azadirachta indica; prompt on Azadirachta; accept neem cake]
Himalayas [or Sagarmatha]
Madagascar [or Republic of Madagascar; or Repoblikan'i Madagasikara; or République de Madagascar]
parts: Name this source of the antifungal azadirachtin, which sparked a 10-year patent battle with W. R. Grace about its status as "ancient Indian knowledge." Cosmetics often use this plant's brown oil despite its sulfurous odor.
The neem tree grows around this mountain range, whose heritage products include sea buckthorn, red rice, and pink salt. In 2019, many climbers died from overcrowding on this range's highest peak.

The Malaysian government had to issue an infographic demonstrating that neem leaves couldn't cure COVID-19. An herbal tea was promoted as a similar quack cure by Andry Rajoelina, the president of this African country.

answers: Hisham Matar
green [or aḫḍar or akhḍar or variants; accept The Green Book or al-Kitāb al-Aḫḍar]
Teju Cole [or Obayemi Babajide Adetokunbo Onafuwa]
parts: Name this Libyan author of Anatomy of a Disappearance, whose dissident father inspired his books The Return and In the Country of Men.

Hisham Matar has written for London's offshore Arabic newspaper Asharq Al-Awsat, whose pages have this distinctive color. Under Gaddafi, Libya's flag was entirely this color, which also names a book outlining Gaddafi's philosophy.

Matar's associative writing style and artistic influences have drawn comparisons to this Nigerian-American author of Open City and Every Day Is for the Thief. He formerly wrote the On Photography column for The New York Times.

answers: Lidar [accept the backronyms light detection and ranging or light imaging, detection, and ranging; accept 3D laser scanning; prompt on scanning; prompt on lasers or equivalents]
elevation [or depth; accept altitude or height or equivalents]
3D point clouds [prompt on points or point sets; accept Point Cloud Library]
parts: Identify this technology used in high-end sensors sold by Velodyne. Valeo devices that use this technology in some Audi vehicles have only four vertical resolution lines.

One application of Lidar is collecting data for topographic maps and bathymetric charts, which use contour lines to connect spots with an equal value of this quantity. It can also be measured with an altimeter.

Most Lidar systems store these virtual objects in .las files. PCL software is used for "registration" that aligns these collections of spatial measurements, which represent 3D features, and which are often converted into polygon meshes.

answers: Saudi Arabia [or Kingdom of Saudi Arabia; or Al-Mamlakah al-ʿArabīyah as-Saʿūdīyah; accept Graveyard of Clerics: Everyday Activism in Saudi Arabia]
Harry Potter (The author is J. K. Rowling.)
music concerts [accept answers like live music events; prompt on shows] (The canceled concert was by Nicki Minaj.)
parts: Identify this country whose sportswashing efforts have included hosting the 2020 Dakar Rally.
One chapter of Ménoret's Graveyard of Clerics documents a debate over this fantasy series, whose author criticized terms like "people who menstruate" in 2020 anti-trans remarks.

Saudi Arabia announced its plans to relax its guardianship laws on the same day that a high-profile event of this kind was canceled in the country. Hiba Tawaji participated in a groundbreaking event of this type in Saudi Arabia.

answers: recidivism rates
Pittsburgh [accept Pittsburgh Robotics Cluster; accept Allegheny County or Allegheny Family Screening Tool]
LinkedIn [prompt on Microsoft] (The co-founder was Reid Hoffman.)
parts: ProPublica found that COMPAS's algorithm for predicting this phenomenon disproportionately marked Black defendants as high-risk. This term refers to a convicted criminal committing a new crime.

A screening tool called the AFST can predict a child's risks in this city and its surrounding county. In 2015, Uber staffed its self-driving lab with numerous researchers from a robotics lab in this city that also spawned Chris Urmson's start-up Aurora.

DJ Patil, a former Chief Scientist at this company, helped shape the Precision Medicine Initiative while serving as Obama's Chief Data Scientist. A Democratic megadonor who co-founded this company has promoted the business strategy "Blitzscaling."

answers: CrossFit, Inc. [accept Reebok CrossFit Games]
erector spinae [accept spinal erectors; accept iliocostalis lumborum or longissimus or sacrospinalis; prompt on erectors]
intensity [or word forms; accept high-intensity interval training or HIIT; prompt on difficulty or similar answers; accept rating of perceived exertion; accept VO2 max]
parts: Name this fitness company that popularized kettlebells in the US with its early morning "workouts of the day." Reebok sponsors this company's annual games, first held in 2007.

CrossFit routines often include the "Good Morning" exercise, which targets these stabilizing lower back muscles. The rectus abdominis antagonizes these muscles, which control posture by driving back extension.

CrossFit cardio routines often feature "interval training" that periodically reaches high values of this quantity. Exercise physiology contrasts volume with this quantity, which is measured with RPE or inferred from oxygen consumption.

answers: Hugo Awards
H. P. Lovecraft [or Howard Phillips Lovecraft]
Victor LaValle
parts: Name these worldwide awards targeted by the failed "Sad Puppies" and "Rabid Puppies" campaigns that opposed winners like Connie Willis.
Hugo winner Nnedi Okorafor ("NED-ee oh-COR-uh-for") also won the World Fantasy Award, which, until 2015, was a bust of this racist author. The game Bloodborne draws on this author's Cthulhu mythos.

This author of Slapboxing with Jesus retold Lovecraft's "The Horror of Red Hook" from a Black perspective in The Ballad of Black Tom. The antiquarian book dealer Apollo Kagwa searches for his vanished wife in a fantastical New York in this author's novel The Changeling.

answers: broadband internet [accept high-speed internet or fiber internet or cable internet; prompt on internet access; do not accept or prompt on "cable"]
Ajit Pai [or Ajit Varadaraj Pai]
OneWeb [accept OneWeb Satellite]
parts: Identify this technology that Google operates in Kansas City and Austin. Jeb Bush wrote a 2020 essay in Slate calling for a 100-billion-dollar investment in this technology, which is not available to 21 million Americans, many in rural areas.
This FCC chairman under Donald Trump has worked against municipal broadband schemes and is a staunch opponent of net neutrality.
In 2020, the UK government purchased a 45% stake in this company that went bankrupt trying to build a satellite constellation for low-Earth-orbit internet.

answers: ancestry [accept word forms like ancestors or ancestral; accept most recent common ancestor or last common ancestor; accept Ancestry.com; prompt on lineage or common descent or similar answers]
maximum likelihood estimation [or MLE; accept Randomized Axelerated Maximum Likelihood]
contagious [or clonally transmissible; or sexually trasmitted; or communicable; or infectious; accept  equivalents and word forms; accept canine transmissible venereal tumor]
parts: Identify this genetic concept often traced from a "last common" individual and increasingly tracked on genetic genealogy sites like 23andMe.

While the program STRUCTURE infers ancestry contributions with a Bayesian ("BAY-zee-in") algorithm, ADMIXTURE relies on this phylogenetic approach. This approach is also used by the tree-building programs RAxML and IQ-TREE.
ADMIXTURE is a common tool to study dog genomics. Dogs are plagued by a tumor called CTVT that has this unusual property, like devil facial tumor disease and many cancers in marine bivalves.

answers: GiveWell
malaria [accept Against Malaria Foundation; accept Malaria Consortium]
iodized salt [prompt on salt; accept iodine or I2; accept universal salt iodization]
parts: Identify this Silicon Valley-based organization that seeks to promote "effective altruism" by ranking charities.
GiveWell rankings are topped by charities that seek to reduce this disease by "seasonal chemoprevention" and distributing nets to reduce bites from mosquitoes transmitting Plasmodium.

Another GiveWell standout charity is GAIN's USI program, which strives to eliminate cognitive development disorders by distributing this good. Basil Hetzel helped popularize this product, which, like selenium, can prevent Kashin–Beck disease.

answers: nail salons [accept manicures or pedicures or other answers about nails; prompt on beauty industry or salons or spas]
Vietnamese-Americans [or Người Mỹ gốc Việt; or Người Việt hải ngoại]
Center for Investigative Reporting [or CIR]
parts: Identify this female-dominated industry whose labor exploitation was exposed in a 2015 New York Times piece by Sarah Maslin Nir. A resulting task force recommended improved ventilation to protect this industry's workers from perchloroethylene.

The documentary Nailed It explores why women of this ethnicity run many nail and hair salons. A Robert Olen Butler book focuses on this ethnicity's diaspora in New Orleans, where they serve bánh mì as po' boys.
This news NGO tracked the "Ghost Fleet" that forced Vietnamese migrants to fish for sharks in El Salvador. This NGO owns The Bay Citizen and produces the podcast Reveal.

answers: Ludwig Wittgenstein [or Ludwig Josef Johann Wittgenstein; accept Wittgenstein's Mistress; accept Wittgenstein's Nephew or Wittgensteins Neffe]
George Berkeley ("BARK-lee") [or Bishop Berkeley; accept Berkeley's World: An Examination of the Three Dialogues]
Edmund Husserl [or Edmund Gustav Albrecht Husserl; accept The Formation of Husserl's Concept of Constitution]
parts: This thinker inspired a sort-of post-apocalyptic David Markson novel named for his "Mistress." A Thomas Bernhard novel follows the mentally ill "nephew" of this author of Philosophical Investigations.

In Jostein Gaarder's ("YOO-stain GOR-der’s") Sophie's World, Sophie realizes that she is fictional from this thinker's argument that all things are sensed by the infinite mind of God. Tom Stoneham examined this "subjective idealist's" "world" in a study of his three-part 1713 magnum opus.

Renée often mocks this later idealist in Muriel Barbery's The Elegance of the Hedgehog. Herman Van Breda saved this thinker's archives from the Nazis and taught Robert Sokolowski, who examined his concept of "constitution."

answers: Psycho [accept 24 Hour Psycho]
Christian Marclay [or Christian Ernest Marclay]
an office [accept Office Killer or Office Space]
parts: Douglas Gordon slowed down the projection of this film to around two frames per second to make it last 24 hours. That gave viewers ample time to examine the shower scene in this Alfred Hitchcock film.
Images of clocks from various films reflect the actual time of day in this artist's 24-hour-long film, The Clock. He also created Tape Fall.

Untitled Film Stills artist Cindy Sherman made her directorial debut with a 1997 film titled for a killer in one of these places who relocates corpses to her basement. A 1999 cult film named for these places was based on the animated "Milton" shorts.

answers: Tash Aw [or Aw Ta-Shi]
Crazy Rich Asians [accept China Rich Girlfriend or Rich People Problems]
Moshin Hamid
parts: Name this Malaysian-British author who depicted a Communist from the colonial Kinta Valley in The Harmony Silk Factory. Brothers grow up on opposite sides of the Konfrontasi in this author's Map of the Invisible World.
Tash Aw's novel Five Star Billionaire concerns immigrants seeking their fortunes in Shanghai, while this Kevin Kwan trilogy focuses on the already-wealthy in Singapore.
Five Star Billionaire is titled for a fake self-help book. This Pakistan-born author of Exit West wrote another novel structured as a self-help book, How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia.

answers: City of David [or Ir David; accept Wadi Hilweh; accept Ir David Foundation or Elad; prompt on Silwan; prompt on the Old City of Jerusalem or Ha'Ir Ha'Atiqah, or al-Balda al-Qadimah; do not accept or prompt on "Tower of David" or "Migdal David"]
aerial cable cars [or sky tram; or aerial tram; accept ropeway; accept aerial gondolas, though not if they're talking about the Venetian kind]
La Paz [or Nuestra Señora de La Paz; or Chuqi Yapu Marka]
parts: Name this controversial archaeological site southeast of Jerusalem's Western Wall that is promoted by a namesake foundation, which also funds the nearby Givati ("geev-ah-TEE") Parking Lot dig. This site allegedly contains the Pool of Siloam that was fed by Gihon Spring in the reign of Hezekiah.

A 2019 New York Times article criticized the plan to link the City of David and Western Wall via one of these systems, bypassing much of the Palestinian Silwan neighborhood. Portland opened one of these systems to OHSU in 2006.
The Mi Teleférico cable car system links this city to El Alto. The Palacio Quemado is in this executive capital of Bolivia, while the Supreme Court is in Sucre.

answers: Squeegee men [or Squeegee bandits or Squeegee merchants or similar]
Rudy Giuliani [or Rudolph William Louis Giuliani]
record store [or record shop; or music store; accept answers like businesses that sell used CDs or tapes]
parts: Identify these people, who in the '80s and '90s would often start washing the windows of cars stopped at traffic lights unbidden and then demand payment.
Squeegee men were some of the main targets of this mayor of New York City whose 2008 presidential bid was largely based on his public image of leadership after 9/11.

During the second year of Giuliani's tenure, seven people were killed in retaliation for a Jewish landlord evicting a Black owner of one of these businesses in Harlem. Eliot Spitzer sued these businesses for fixing prices in conjunction with Trans World Entertainment.

answers: yarn bombing [accept yarnstorming; accept guerrilla knitting or guerrilla crocheting; accept urban knitting or urban crocheting; accept graffiti knitting or graffiti crocheting; accept fabric bombing; prompt on art bombing]
spiders [prompt on arachnids or arthropods or other non-specific answers]
underwater museums [or museums of underwater art; accept underwater shipwreck; accept equivalents; accept Museo Subacuático de Arte; prompt on sculpture parks or other non-underwater answers]
parts: Name this type of street art installation that originated in the early 2000s. Magda Sayeg may have invented this practice, which involves decorating trees, poles, and other objects by covering them with an eponymous material.
Magda Sayeg's yarn bombing group has created pants for the eight legs of one of Louise Bourgeois's Maman sculptures depicting these creatures.

Crochet artist Olek controversially created one of her "wearable sculptures" out of Jason deCaires Taylor's Time Bomb in this sort of place. A recently opened Greek museum near Alonissos in one of these places features four thousand clay amphora.
